plugins.name: UI Stories (Assets Showcase Generator)
plugins.description:
UI Stories Plugin is a showcase generator that streamlines the design process by organizing and documenting assets.


How It Works:


– Flexible Selection: Begin by selecting any component, component set, component instance, or design element like frames or shapes. The plugin automatically identifies the related component sets or components linked to your selection and displays a list for you to choose which components to document.


– Comprehensive Documentation: If no specific selection is made, the plugin will catalog all component sets and components throughout your file. It may take longer if your file includes numerous components with multiple variations.


The plugin is designed to efficiently handle large datasets to prevent freezing during rendering. However, if rendering all showcases becomes overly time-consuming, consider using the component-by-component rendering option for a quicker and more manageable process.


– Theme-Specific Documentation: For files containing multiple themes, the plugin generates themed documentation frames. For 'Dark' themes, components are displayed against a black background, while other themes use a light gray background.


Default background values are customizable (e.g., _DemoPage-darkBackgroundForComponentsDemo as #251F1F for dark themes and _DemoPage-lightBackgroundForComponentsDemo as #E9E8E8 for others).


You can adjust these backgrounds, including setting them to transparent, to suit your project needs. Once you modify these color settings, the plugin will remember your preferences and apply these settings in all subsequent operations, ensuring consistency across your documentation process.


– Rendering Options: You can choose to display the component showcases directly on the active page, where a new frame will appear at the top of your layer list. Alternatively, opt for documentation on a newly created page, where the plugin will generate a timestamped page at the bottom of your page list.


– Detailed Property Display: The plugin renders a table for properties that have multiple values, ensuring detailed visual documentation. Properties with only a single value are neatly listed below the table, providing a clear and organized overview. At the end of each table, a timestamp indicates when the showcase was rendered. Additionally, if a component has a description, it will also be displayed.


– Testing your components: For components that lack variants or have errors, I display "N/A" in the cell instead of the component, allowing you to easily test for missing variants. Keep in mind that the absence of some variants is normal, as they may not always be necessary.


As a testing tool, you can also change the background color in all cells simultaneously, visually testing how all your components and their variants appear against different backgrounds. This feature enhances the ability to ensure visual consistency across your designs.


Key Features:

– Generate Overview in Seconds: Automatically generate detailed views of all components and component sets within your Figma file. Whether you select specific components or document the entire file, the plugin provides a visual inventory on a single page.


– Theme-Specific Rendering: The plugin facilitates rendering components against different themes, making it easy to test and compare visual consistency across various backgrounds.


– Efficiency Boost: Save valuable design time by generating demonstrations for components directly within Figma. This feature helps you understand how your assets function, identify missing elements, and provide clear visualizations that save development time—ensuring design integrity.


– Dynamic Updates: Re-run the plugin at any time to refresh your documentation as your designs evolve, ensuring your component overviews always reflect the latest changes.


Coming Soon:

– Smart grouping of non-component sets

– Conversion of all interface blocks into components

– Extended inventory capabilities, allowing inventorying variables and local styles for enhanced design system management and documentation within Figma

accepted.name: Olga Stogova
accepted.description: Experienced Full Stack Engineer Specializing in TypeScript/React and Advanced Interface Development

plugins.tagline: Create detailed showcases of your Figma components' properties

plugins.name: Flowchart to JSON
plugins.description:
FigJam flowchart diagram to JSON


Select the root element, and run the plugin. It will generate a JSON representation of the graph interpretation of the flowchart. There are two types of entities: nodes and edges, which model the relation of the flowchart elements. A Node is a, in this case a purple, box with text inside, and an edge is a line connecting the two nodes. All sorts of properties are stored on a node or edge, such as the text, the color and its connections.


View the code on github


Usage


Select a root node and run the plugin. It will copy the JSON to your clipboard, if possible. Coping to clipboard is a bit flaky and may be restricted by your environment in some way. As a fallback, when the automatic copying fails, a window will open displaying the JSON as plain text.


Parsing


Note that the resulting JSON may be cyclic, by the nature of the flowchart. These kinds of JSONs can be parsed with the library circ-json


API

The starting point is always a Node.


interface Element {
text: string;
id: string;
type: "NODE" | "EDGE",
}

interface Edge extends Element {
from: Node,
to?: Node,
fromSide?: 'NONE' | 'AUTO' | 'TOP' | 'LEFT' | 'BOTTOM' | 'RIGHT',
toSide?: 'NONE' | 'AUTO' | 'TOP' | 'LEFT' | 'BOTTOM' | 'RIGHT',
color?: {r: number, g: number, b: number},
edgeType: 'ELBOWED' | 'STRAIGHT',
directional: "UNI" | "BI"
}

interface Node extends Element {
edges: Edge[],
color?: {r: number, g: number, b: number}
}


Contribute

Please feel free to write a comment, if you experience an issue or have an idea. You may also view the code on github and propose changes.

accepted.name: Maximilian Mairinger
accepted.description: Web advocate, passionate about Typescript, image compression, UI design and emergency medicine. Currently, studying AI at JKU.

plugins.tagline: Generate graph like JSON out of flowchart diagram

plugins.name: Source Foundation
plugins.description:
Bootstrap design system foundation in a few simple steps.


  1. Source Foundation Demo -> Watch onYouTube (11:10)
  2. Source Foundation Deep Dive -> Watch on You Tube (9:43)
  3. How it works → Read on Medium


Colours


Source Foundation generates well-balanced and accessible palettes for light or dark modes. Each palette includes neutrals, brand, semantics and eleven beautiful accent colours to work with. And it is WCAG 2.2 compliant. 


There is a playground file with design examples and extended documentation on how it works.


Learn more about the colour system →


Typography


For typography there are tree scales:

  1. Major third
  2. Minor third
  3. Major second


And three base font sizes

  1. Compact (13/16): Suits for native desktop applications
  2. Base (15/20): Well balanced size that works for majority of use cases
  3. Large (17/24): Touch oriented UIs


Spacing


There are four pre-calculated spacing scales:

  1. Compact (16): Suits for native desktop applications
  2. Base (20): Well balanced size that works for majority of use cases
  3. Large (24): Max negative space
  4. Touch (16): Optimised for touch devices


Radii


There are three pre-calculated radii scales

  1. Compact (4): Suits for native desktop applications
  2. Base (6): Well balanced size that works for majority of use cases
  3. Large (8): Touch oriented UIs


Dev Tools


Connect Source Foundation with development


Tailwind CSS Integration →

Integrate Source Foundation with Tailwind CSS


Node CLI Generator →

Export settings to build CSS variables file with command line tool

accepted.name: Pavel Kiselev
accepted.description: One man army

plugins.tagline: Design system foundation generator. Generate colours, spacing, radii and typography variables

plugins.name: Country Flags
plugins.description:
The Country Flags plugin allows you to easily insert SVG flags of various countries into your Figma designs. It provides a user-friendly interface for browsing and selecting flags, with options to filter by continent. 


This plugin is particularly useful for designers working on international projects, travel applications, financial services, or any design that requires country representation.


Usage Guide

  1. Launch the Plugin: Open your Figma design and start the Country Flags plugin.
  2. Browse Flags: Use the continent filter if needed, then scroll through the flag grid.
  3. Select a Flag: Click on your desired flag.
  4. Insertion: The flag will be automatically inserted into your current Figma page as an SVG.
  5. Customize: After insertion, you can resize, recolor, or modify the flag as needed using Figma's standard tools.

accepted.name: Soliudeen Ogunsola
accepted.description: Product Designer.

plugins.tagline: Insert high-quality SVG country flags instantly

plugins.name: Animate Timeline
plugins.description:
Interaction Guide Creation Tool


Escape the hassle of creating interaction guides! While essential for design projects, creating interaction guides can often be time-consuming and labor-intensive. To alleviate this burden, we have developed a groundbreaking Figma plugin. By simply inputting Action attributes, this Figma plugin automatically generates timelines and interaction guides, making your workflow more efficient and straightforward.


Key Features of the Plugin

1.Automatic Timeline Generation

By entering Action attributes, the plugin automatically creates a timeline. This allows you to easily visualize the sequence and timing of interactions, facilitating the creation of more intuitive and clear guides. The timeline and guide are completed quickly and accurately without the need for manual input, greatly aiding in smooth communication with developers.

2.Time Reduction

No more need for manually creating complex interaction guides. The plugin's automatic timeline generation significantly reduces the time required to write guides. Through automated processes, designers can focus more on important creative tasks.

3.User-Friendly Interface

The plugin features an easy-to-use interface that anyone can use effortlessly. Designed for intuitive use, it can be utilized immediately without a complicated learning curve.

4.Accurate Interaction Definition

Based on the input code attributes, the plugin accurately defines interactions. This helps in creating consistent and error-free guides.


How to Use

  1. Install the plugin and open your project in Figma.
  2. Select the element for which you want to create an interaction guide.
  3. Enter the code attributes into the plugin panel.
  4. The plugin will automatically generate the timeline and complete the interaction guide.


Conclusion

Stop wasting time on complex interaction guide creation. Use our Figma plugin to create interaction guides efficiently and accurately. Experience the Figma plugin that reduces the time spent on guide creation now!


Product

  1. manager - lee sangmin
  2. design - kim yeoreum, park sumin
  3. developer(dev) - hong sungin

accepted.name: sungin.hong
accepted.description: Interaction Designer

plugins.name: CoShuffler
plugins.description:
A tool for randomly assigning colors to a selection of objects from a chosen color palette!


Usage

Quickly apply an assortment of colors to large selection of objects.

  • Create cool, complex patterns for backgrounds!
  • Make color iterations of logos, buttons, etc!
  • Mock up data visualizations without the hassle!


Instructions:

  1. Install CoShuffler by pressing the "Install" button in the top-right corner of this page.
  2. In your figma file, open the CoShuffler by right clicking on the canvas -> Plugins -> CoShuffler
  3. Set your palette: Select a group of objects which contain your desired color palette, and then click "Set colors".
  4. Select your objects: Once your palette is set, select one or more objects that you want to shuffle
  5. Start Shuffling: Click "GO!" to start shuffling between colors in your palette!
  6. (Optional) On the "info" page, choose whether to enable or disable strokes and fills from being adjusted by the CoShuffler.


Constraints:

  • Currently, CoShuffler will ignore groups, frames, and components. If you want to shuffle objects in groups, either directly select the objects or ungroup them.
  • Image and gradient fills will be ignored.
  • If your object has multiple fills, CoShuffler will only change the top fill. It won't affect opacity settings of fills either.


If you have any complaints, concerns, or want to share what you're making with CoShuffler, you can reach me via email or Instagram. Cheers, and happy shuffling! 🥳

plugins.name: FigTrans
plugins.description:
FigTrans lets you translate your UI or prototype into your desired language. This plugin was created to help users translate their work and share it with everyone.


Languages

The plugin uses Google Translate API; all languages supported by this API are also supported in this plugin. There is also an option to use auto-detection feature of Google Translate API or identify the source language manually.


Translation

You can choose either translating the whole texts in the page or selected texts only. This gives you the flexibility while using this plugin. There is also a counter to give you information on how many texts are translated already.


Overall, FigTrans is a helpful plugin for everyone who wishes their UI or prototype to be understood in a matter of clicks.

plugins.name: Monochromatic - Color Picker
plugins.description:
color harmony refers to the property that certain aesthetically pleasing color combinations have. These combinations create pleasing contrasts and consonances that are said to be harmonious.




Monochromatic color schemes are made up of variations of one color. This can be done by adding white to a color to create tints, or by adding black to a color to create shades. By using a monochromatic color scheme, you can create a sense of unity and harmony in your design.




A monochromatic color scheme is all about one singular color, but with all its beautiful variations in shades, tints, and tones. Think of it as a family portrait of a single color, where black and white are often included as the most extreme family members!




Two colors that are on opposite sides of the color wheel. This combination provides a high contrast and high impact color combination – together, these colors will appear brighter and more prominent.




Complementary colors are pairs of colors which, when combined or mixed, cancel each other out by producing a grayscale color like white or black. When placed next to each other, they create the strongest contrast for those two colors.




Complementary colors may also be called "opposite colors".




Three colors that are evenly spaced on the color wheel. This provides a high contrast color scheme, but less so than the triadic color combination — making it more versatile. This combination creates bold, vibrant color palettes.




A traditionally-balanced triadic color scheme focuses on one dominant color, with the other two evenly spaced colors both serving as accents. Triadic colors stand out from one another and make for a vibrant, lively color palette regardless of which particular colors are used.




Four colors that are evenly spaced on the color wheel. Tetradic color schemes are bold and work best if you let one color be dominant, and use the others as accents. The more colors you have in your palette, the more difficult it is to balance,




The tetradic (double complementary) scheme is the richest of all the schemes because it uses four colors organized into two complementary color pairs. Tetrad is a very aggressive color scheme, needing very good planning and very emotional approach to relations of these colors.

accepted.description:
This page would be your one-stop shop for all things UI/UX creativity and a treasure trove of tools to elevate your designs.

www.beforepost.com

plugins.name: Join paths
plugins.description:
A simple utility for designers who work with complex vector illustrations and icons. This tool seamlessly joins two separate paths, making it effortless to create continuous, flowing designs just like you can do in Adobe Illustrator. Whether you're working with straight lines or intricate curves, Path Connector intelligently identifies the closest endpoints and merges them with precision.


It preserves all styling attributes and even works within frames, maintaining your design's integrity. With an option to replace original paths or create new ones, this plugin offers flexibility for various workflows.


How it works

  1. Select two line paths
  2. Place 2 of the open ends of the line paths within 2 px of one another
  3. Connect with the plugin
plugins.tagline: Join vector line paths without the hassle

plugins.name: Smartling
plugins.description:
Without leaving Figma, you can submit prototypes for professional, machine or pseudo translation to get the gist for what the localized environment will look like before you put your “pencil down” on a project.


When you start translating and localizing your content as soon as the design prototypes are available, the entire process for shipping new product gets faster. Smartling’s localization plugin for Figma seamlessly connects your designers with Smartling’s translation service in just one click.


You prototype user experiences in English because that’s the primary language of your product or digital environment. You check to see if text fits within buttons, how layouts change with different devices and make design decisions based on your preferred user experience. Why not do this for your global user base, too?

plugins.name: Golden Spiral
plugins.description:
Golden Spiral is a powerful plugin designed for Figma that empowers designers with a suite of tools to work with the golden ratio, a mathematical ratio commonly found in nature and often used in design for aesthetic appeal and balance.


Buy me coffee


With Golden Spiral, designers can effortlessly incorporate golden spirals and rectangles into their designs, explore golden numbers, and analyze objects for adherence to the golden ratio.


Key Features:


  • Create Golden Spirals and Rectangles: Instantly generate golden spirals and rectangles, allowing designers to integrate these aesthetically pleasing shapes into their designs with ease.
  • Golden Number Calculator: Obtain the corresponding golden numbers by simply inputting a number, providing designers with valuable insights into the golden ratio and its application in design.
  • Golden Ratio Checker: Quickly determine if an object follows the golden ratio by selecting it, helping designers ensure harmony and balance in their compositions.
  • Custom Spiral Creation: Tailor spirals to specific design requirements by defining parameters such as count, width, height, and choose between spiral, rectangles, or both, empowering designers with flexibility and control over their creations.
  • Automated Golden Shapes: Automatically generate golden spirals or rectangles based on the size of selected objects, streamlining the design process and promoting consistency in design compositions.

This plugin will not work with old layouts.

Any issues please send us an email to support@claritee.io or reach out to us using the chat in Claritee.

plugins.name: Quick Commands
plugins.description:
Powerful extension for Quick Actions Bar


Quick Commands is a plugin live in Figma quick actions bar, enter one or more commands and it will do the actions for you.


Optimize your design process with keyboard and minimal cursor movement.



🪁 Try it out


  1. Set a shortcut for Quick Commands Plugin (Find the guide in the playground file. My keyboard is HHKB and I set the shortcut to Control + Q).
  2. Select some frame or rectangle layers and open the plugin, you will get an input bar.
  3. Type a command like “w80” and press “Enter” key, layers width will be set to 80px.
  4. Reopen the plugin and type more commands like “f#1 b#2db bb10 rt8 rb0”, these 5 commands will be executed in turn. Layers fill color will be set to #111111, the stroke color will be set to #22DDBB (to do this, you can also replace "b#" in the command with "st#”), the border bottom width will be set to 10px, the top corners radius will be set to 8px and the bottom corners radius will be set to 0.
  5. Every time a command is run, it is saved to the history list, next time you open the plugin, you will see the history list. So you can just select some other layers and redo the previous commands in a quick way.
  6. Find more commands in the list of commands below, some command need to input a value, some commands not accept a value. Feel free to try every command in the plugin, if you enter an invalid command I will return an error message before the command runs.



🎱 Commands List


The commands are inspired by atomic CSS and designed for simplicity. Type letters in the plugin to discover related commands


Click this link to open the commands list

https://figmaplugin.com/quick-commands/commands-list


This plugin is currently in beta and some commands may be modified in the future.



Feedback

Discord: https://discord.gg/ZsdnDhhTH8


Changelog

  • V0.1.1(Beta) 2022.12.13 - Add commands: content box, border box
  • V0.1 (Beta) 2022.12.08

accepted.name: Tank
accepted.description: Product Designer / Creator

plugins.name: Export Text styles to Json file
plugins.description:
This Figma plugin allows designers and developers to streamline their workflow by exporting all local text styles from a Figma file into a JSON format. Perfect for ensuring consistency in design across projects and platforms.


  • Easy Export: With just one click, export all your Figma file's text styles into a JSON file.
  • Saves Time: Eliminates the need for manual transcription of text styles into code, saving time for both designers and developers.
  • Consistency Across Platforms: Use the exported JSON to maintain consistent text styles across web and mobile platforms.
  • Simple to Use: No coding knowledge required. Simply install the plugin and click to export.
  • Enhanced Workflow: Ideal for teams looking to automate and streamline their design-to-development handoff process.
  • File Name Included: The exported JSON also includes the name of the Figma file, making it easy to track and organize style guides.


Designed to make your design workflow more efficient and consistent. Try it out now!

plugins.name: Export Filtered Variables
plugins.description:
This plug-in is made for my personal workflow. I like having token files for its role and mode then combine them through style dictionary. So, I tweaked Figma's official sample code to add filters for collections and modes.


Differences from Figma's code:

  • You can export specific collection or mode.
  • Token attributes for Style Dictionary (If variable type is color or its name contains "sizing", "spacing", "borderRadius", "dimension", "borderWidth").
  • No comment inserted in the result if collection is specified.
plugins.tagline: Export variables from specific collection and mode

plugins.name: Transifex Figma Plugin
plugins.description:
Transifex and Figma

Accelerate your localization workflow and go to market faster by bringing your Product, Design and Localization teams closer using the Figma plugin for Transifex. Easily send your design texts from Figma to Transifex’s powerful translation management system (TMS) to get them translated. Pull the translated texts back to Figma to validate internationalization (i18n) and resolve any translation issues before coding begins.


Let your designers preview the localized designs and make all necessary adjustments right away, to avoid costly delays in refactoring localization bugs and give your localization users a great UX. Give your translators rich context with screenshots to let them understand where and how the translation will appear so that they deliver higher quality translations.


Boost collaboration between your designers and translators. Deliver new digital experiences faster.


Using with Transifex

Connecting Figma with Transifex


1. Make sure that you have access to at least one organization and one project in Transifex.

2. Install the “Transifex Figma Plugin” in your Figma app.

3. Open your Figma file.

4. Go to plugins and select “Transifex Figma Plugin”.

6. Add your Transifex credentials in the “Settings” tab: First you need to connect with Transifex using an API token. Generate this token from your Transifex account under User Settings => API token. After generating the token, copy and paste it in the related input box in the Figma plugin and click “Connect”.


You should complete the following plugin settings after connecting with Transifex:

Organization: the desired organization to work with.

Project: the desired project that these Figma strings will be associated with.

Resource: the desired resource of the selected project to push strings to. If you don’t have any resources you can try to create one using the action “Create a new resource” (note that you should have the adequate permissions in order to perform this action).


After setting the options, click “Save”.


Using the plugin


1. Start selecting the Figma layers that you want to send, or “push”, to your Transifex resource for translation.

2. Your selection will collect your text layers as strings in the main window of the plugin, under both the “Push strings to Transifex” and “Pull strings from Transifex” tabs.

3. To remove any unwanted strings from the selection in the “Push” or “Pull” tabs, click the X to the right of the string. That string will be removed from the current selection list.

4. Click the “Push” button to send the selected strings to Transifex and add them to the connected resource. After pushing the strings you can check to see that they were successfully sent using the “View resource in Transifex” link. Also you have the option to upload screenshots if you have selected “Upload Screenshots”. The strings will be translated according to the workflow set up in the Transifex project.

5. By default the plugin will automatically generate screenshots of your Figma frames and include them with the pushed strings in Transifex. The strings for translation will be automatically mapped to the screenshots in Transifex to provide visual context of your Figma designs to your translators and ensure the quality of the translation. Optionally you can disable screenshot generation for any string push by deselecting the “Upload Screenshots” checkbox in the “Push Strings to Transifex” tab.

6. You can use the “Replace Resource Strings” feature to clean extra or outdated strings out of your Transifex resources. if this option is checked when you click the “Push” button to send strings to Transifex, then all of the strings currently in the connected resource will be purged and replaced with the current selection only. This option should be used carefully, especially with resources shared by other users. If you are sure you want to replace all the strings in the resource with the current selection, click “OK” in the confirmation dialog. The resource strings will be replaced, and the “Replace” option will be reset to deactivated. All of your previous translations remain in the translation memory (TM) so you and your team can reuse them, unless they are also deleted from the TM in Transifex.

7. To pull translations back from Transifex to Figma, first select the Figma layers you want to get translations for and then click the “Pull” button in the “Pull Strings from Transifex” tab. You have the option to pull them in all languages or in a specific one by selecting it in the “Language” dropdown. The pull operation will create a new page in your Figma file for every language with the same name of the selected page and the language code as prefix, and automatically insert translations for the selected strings.


About Transifex

Founded in Greece and now headquartered in Silicon Valley, Transifex helps companies - from Startups to the Enterprise - go global. With our top-rated SaaS-based Translation and Localization Platform, organizations can easily translate digital content such as websites, mobile apps, games, video, help centers, subtitles, and more on a continuous basis. Leading companies including Eventbrite, Salesforce, HubSpot, Waze, and Microsoft rely on Transifex to achieve a truly multilingual, international presence. For more information, visit www.transifex.com, and follow Transifex on Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn.


Learn More

Read our documentation about the Transifex Figma plugin: https://help.transifex.com/en/articles/6213576-figma-plugin


Contact us at support@transifex.com with any questions or feature requests.
plugins.tagline: Localize your Figma designs with Transifex

The pull operation will create a new page in your Figma file for every language with the same name of the selected page and the language code as prefix, and automatically insert translations for the selected strings.


About Transifex

Founded in Greece and now headquartered in Silicon Valley, Transifex helps companies - from Startups to the Enterprise - go global. With our top-rated SaaS-based Translation and Localization Platform, organizations can easily translate digital content such as websites, mobile apps, games, video, help centers, subtitles, and more on a continuous basis. Leading companies including Eventbrite, Salesforce, HubSpot, Waze, and Microsoft rely on Transifex to achieve a truly multilingual, international presence. For more information, visit www.transifex.com, and follow Transifex on Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn.


Learn More

Read our documentation about the Transifex Figma plugin: https://help.transifex.com/en/articles/6213576-figma-plugin


Contact us at support@transifex.com with any questions or feature requests.

plugins.name: Next
plugins.description:
Next pans through the canvas frames on the current page using a minimal, next / previous interface.


Automatic Path

By default, frames will be shown in left-to-right reading order, with a transition between each. If a frame name ends with a bullet (•), the transition will be instant. Frames in sections are completed before moving to the next section.


Camera Paths

If a vector path named "Camera" is present, the control points of that path will be used for each step, with full easing between them.


If these points overlap with a frame, that frame will be used to set the camera view, with the transitions from the control point.


Control point miters can adjust the flow of animation:

  • Miter - Pause at point (Default)
  • Bevel - Instantly transition to point
  • Round - Continue through point


Keys and Modifiers

  • When the panel is focused, keyboard will advance and allow vertical movement in automatic grids. (Arrows, WASD, Space/Backspace)
  • Holding shift will slow the transitions.
  • 0–9 keys change animation speed between 0–999ms
  • +/- adjust zoom level


Links - Source Code - Discord
plugins.tagline: Glide between frames with a minimal UI
